<!member_group:bd07d910-8747-4dd7-8aba-88272899bc6a|Ryan Haraki> First thing is grabbing a ~45min time with them to:
- download repo (Rod is invited to github)
- send web and backend .env variables
- show them how to make the 5 tabs and startup all the services
- on app.ando.so, invite them to our workspace (via members tab). Maybe sure to invite them on app.ando.so, not localhost, or else the email link they get will redirect to localhost

Hey team! Here's a quick update on the discussion topics:

1. **October Edition Settings:** Sara requested team feedback on the settings for the upcoming edition of Ando. Link: [Notion](https://www.notion.so/Settings).

2. **Onboarding Process:** Ryan asked Peter about successful strategies to onboard engineers effectively. Peter shared a starting process involving repository access and environment setup.

3. **Process for Small Changes:** Ryan asked about handling small code changes, like making links clickable. Peter suggested creating a ticket and passing it through QA for a final review by Sara.

4. **QA Process Alignment:** Sara is preparing a process guide to ensure alignment on QA practices, expected to be shared on Thursday.

5. **Weekly Engineering Update:** Lily asked for a summary of last week's engineering work.

Let me know if you need more details or further assistance!

btw <!member_group:77831cd6-e47f-47f2-803c-dbb81a2e5f17|Peter> are we caching messages at send time? or what do we need to do to make sure the ones that we hit "send" on aren't dropped if we're offline briefly
eg when hotspot disconnects

To chime in, caching pertains to messages we load items in a workspace. At the moment when a message is sent, we show an "optimistic" outcome of the message locally while we post the message. If there is a network issue the optimistic message will roll-back (I don't believe we do retry logic)

We'd need to implement an IndexedDB or some other local storage to persist messages locally + retry logic to send when back online

<!member_group:01dd2d63-1634-45f3-99c7-2397e9dd2073|oliver@ando.so>, I have an important observation. This is for you, as well as the many many more future non-technical builders at this legendary company. And it is this:
Getting PRs merged to the codebase authored by 1) a non-technical builder and 2) a technical builder have different levels of cost on the team. üí≥

Meaning ‚Äî the code in PRs authored by #1 is usually less maintainable. It also isn‚Äôt understood as well. Without a technical builder making it more maintainable and understanding it (üí≥), product velocity slows over time. üêå
In contrast, PRs authored by #2 has less cost (there's at least awareness of maintainability + is understood by at least 1 person, the author!).
This isn‚Äôt inherently a problem, but it does create an issue of accountability. #1 ‚Äúships the feature‚Äù but really, #2 is accountable for understanding it and making it maintainable.ü•≤

And actually #2 SHOULD be responsible for the code, because‚Ä¶ he regularly dreams of react components at this point, and #1 simply can't do it. On the other hand, the insane value #1 brings to the table is twofold: a) figuring out WHAT to code, and b) saving #2‚Äôs time by letting him review + understand, rather than implement himself.

üß†¬†So given this reality that #2 is responsible for the code and #1 plays support (for code), here are 3 things I think we should start doing starting today:
- #1 keeps PRs short, ideally < 150 lines.
- #2 closes the PR if he thinks it‚Äôll take more time to review + understand than implement himself.
- To avoid wasted work (like #2 closing a PR), #1 and #2 agree on what #1 will code before starting.

On AI code review/code gen: yes it‚Äôs magical. It‚Äôs incredible at generating product surface area and pointing out logical bugs. But it‚Äôs still not great at making larger architectural decisions though (aka, doesn‚Äôt solve maintainability), and doesn‚Äôt help with understanding the code. Therefore, #2 should still review.
But since it‚Äôs good at the nits stuff, let‚Äôs try another thing once our AI code review tools are properly tuned: #1 addresses comments made by AI code review before requesting review.

The way I usually evaluate these kinds of decisions is by separating¬†functional problems¬†from¬†conceptual problems. Channel discovery feels mostly functional -- unless we decide to pull in memory or advanced context, there isn‚Äôt a ton of deep product thinking required here. If there is, the effort to reward value is not there.

On the other hand, things like the¬†agent experience¬†or¬†rules framework¬†are more conceptual, where the ‚Äúhow‚Äù isn‚Äôt obvious. Those areas deserve more deliberate brainstorming because the design space is layered & decisions will have long-term implications.

Everyone describes the failure differently ‚Äî ‚Äúspinning,‚Äù ‚Äúno response,‚Äù ‚Äúagent stuck.‚Äù Humans don‚Äôt realize it‚Äôs the same root cause; AI does.Conversations#support9:07 ‚Äî CS1: ‚ÄúCustomer says ‚Äòdaily sync agent‚Äô just spins indefinitely.‚Äù9:10 ‚Äî CS2: ‚ÄúDifferent customer seeing ‚Äòworkflow never finishes‚Äô on same feature.‚Äù#mobile9:13 ‚Äî Eng1: ‚ÄúAnyone seen the agent freeze after step 3? Mine just hangs.‚Äù#product9:15 ‚Äî PM: ‚ÄúNot sure if this is related, but our retry logic might be breaking again.‚ÄùAI Notification (deduped + synthesized)‚ÄúThere are 4 reports across support, mobile, and product in the last 10 minutes describing the same failure pattern: agents hanging / spinning / not finishing workflows.Here‚Äôs a single consolidated summary + top repro steps + links to all source messages.‚Äù2.¬†Three people ask the same question in different wordsScenarioPeople repeatedly ask a core question (e.g., when is a feature shipping?). You don‚Äôt want to spam with 3 notifications. You want one: ‚ÄúThis question is now a pattern.‚ÄùConversations#sales1:02 ‚Äî AE1: ‚ÄúDo we have an ETA on multi-workspace support? Big customer asking.‚Äù#general1:05 ‚Äî Random IC: ‚ÄúAny update on support for multiple workspaces per org?‚ÄùDM to PM1:08 ‚Äî CSM: ‚ÄúHey, any chance the multi-workspace feature is still on track?‚ÄùAI Notification‚Äú3 people asked about multi-workspace support in the last 6 minutes across sales, general, and DMs. Here‚Äôs a consolidated answer opportunity.Suggested response draft: ‚Ä¶(Click to reply to all in one message or handle individually.)‚Äù3.¬†Repeated signs of ‚Äúsomething is wrong‚Äù but no explicit complaintScenarioSoft signals accumulate ‚Äî this is where embeddings are critical: they surface similar ‚Äúvibes‚Äù in different phrasings.Conversations#productPM: ‚ÄúHmm, my agent took 2 minutes to summarize a 4-line thread.‚Äù#backendEng: ‚ÄúOps latency seems a little high but not sure if it‚Äôs my local.‚Äù#supportCS: ‚ÄúCustomer says chat responses feel slower today.‚ÄùAI Notification‚ÄúThere are 3 latency-related messages across different teams within 15 minutes.They describe similar slow-response symptoms.Combined summary + raw messages attached.‚Äù(99% of companies miss these signals until there‚Äôs an outage.)4.¬†Conflicting instructions / contradictory decisions across channelsScenarioTwo decision-makers make statements that collide. AI should dedupe into a single contradiction notification.Conversations#roadmapPM: ‚ÄúWe are freezing scope for v1. No more new features.‚Äù#designDesigner: ‚ÄúAdding user tagging to v1 since folks requested it.‚Äù#mobileEngineer: ‚ÄúShipping tagging for v1 this week.‚ÄùAI Notification‚ÄúDetected a potential contradiction across 3 threads:‚Äì Roadmap freeze for v1‚Äì Tagging feature being added + implementedShared context suggests these are the same scope area.One consolidated decision review may be needed.‚ÄùThis is dedupe + synthesis over semantically linked but separately stated contradictions.5.¬†Multiple related tasks being created that should be one taskScenarioTeams create separate issues for the same underlying work.Conversations#backendEng: ‚ÄúCreating a ticket to fix webhook retries.‚Äù#integrationsIntegrations Eng: ‚ÄúFiled ‚Äòretry logic broken‚Äô task for Stripe connector.‚Äù#supportCS: ‚ÄúCustomer reported webhooks failing unexpectedly.‚ÄùAI Notification‚ÄúThese 3 new tasks/messages appear to refer to the same webhook-retry issue.Do you want me to merge them into a single parent issue?Consolidated notes + links provided.‚ÄùEmbeddings cluster these tasks around the same failure mode.6.¬†Five micro-updates that are actually one coherent statusScenarioMany people update bits of the same initiative. Humans lose the big picture.Conversations#launch-gtmSales: ‚ÄúSigned off on messaging.‚ÄùMarketing: ‚ÄúDraft landing page v1 ready.‚ÄùEng: ‚ÄúAPI limits finalized.‚ÄùPM: ‚ÄúPricing sheet updated.‚ÄùOps: ‚ÄúSupport FAQ almost done.‚ÄùAI Notification‚Äú5 updates across sales, marketing, eng, PM, ops relate to the Q1 launch.Here‚Äôs a merged status summary (what‚Äôs done / what‚Äôs pending).Should I post a unified status update to #launch-gtm?‚ÄùAI turns scattered noise into an actual heartbeat.7.¬†Three separate hints indicate a user is at risk of churningScenarioCSMs express uncertainty in different channels. Different symptoms. also sth i wanted to discuss on standup today

basically oli let me know that stacks can grow with messages that are days apart, but part of the same 'topic' or 'subject' or whatnot. e.g. if Peter is talking about Artifacts, and sends some msgs abt it in <!channel:50c671ac-2f1f-4357-8bc0-f6fafdb80d6c|engineering> on 12/1 and then on 12/11 sends another set of msgs in <!channel:c608a819-ea5d-4946-b0ec-c006249d39ee|general>  that all gets added to the Artifacts stack

however, i think *time* is still a very important vector for us to consider. there are parts of the app that will require us to have a concept of message bundles (i still really like the word bundles for some reason) that are more temporally related. also important because even an entity like Artifacts evolves over time, a bundle / set / sequence of msgs about Artifacts on 12/11 may contain pretty different information / sentiment on 12/1

so i just wanted us to discuss this and get on the same page about how we're considering this
this was my definition of it^ but we should solidify this as a team

yeah i think Sequences (or whatever we call what we show in the Inbox) should also not pull from different channels, it creates a lot of edge cases as it relates to permissioning and read/unread states. the same Stack topic (ex. Artifact) could have different Events depending on what channels/convos a user has access to. this could end up giving people at the company different understandings of the same topic. marking a Stack "read" in Inbox marks all the component Events read too, but as they're not delivering chronologically, this would lead to confusing read/unread states when a user views messages in a channel vs. in the Inbox.
hmm yea, channels is still prob the best way to do permissions, but need to think more on that\

Agree with this definition of stack. Don't think we have to decide on the "nodes in knowledge graph" part yet, since knowledge graph itself isn't needed yet (for search we'll likely just use a different approach ie. w zeroentropy).

The 2 contenders for nodes in knowledge graph are 1) stacks, and 2) separate more higher level "subject" ex. search feature, or channel UI refresh

yeah i think so too, hence why sequences should prob be scoped to a channel/conversation vs. the entire workspace. whereas stacks could be a workspace thing (would still need to figure out permissions there)

The time piece we'll need to experiment with for stacks (currently not implemented).

we should hammer on some permissions thinking for stacks, sequences, whatever we land on calling them

<!member_group:77831cd6-e47f-47f2-803c-dbb81a2e5f17|Peter> Design consideration for you in stack reranking. Currently I'm implementing something like this:

Step 1: Turbopuffer Retreival
- we embed messages, find similar stacks by summary embedding
- return top 20 candidate IDs

Step 2: Fetch full message content:
- Query postgres for stack's event_list_item_ids
- Concatenate all messages in each stack

Step 3: ZeroEntropy Rerank
- Compare incoming message vs full stack message content & summary

How does this approach look to you overall? What're your thoughts about the middle "hydration" later where we retrieve messages instead of stack summaries
